title: Measuring trogocytosis between ovarian tumor and natural killer cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Coculturing cells with a transwell barrier
Timing: 9–10 h
To confirm that the protein(s) of interest has been acquired by trogocytosis, cocultures separated by a membrane barrier (pore size 3 μm) should be set up with a transwell plate. The large 3 μm pore size allows extracellular vesicles, such as exosomes (100 nm), to pass through but blocks cell – cell contact that is essential for trogocytosis.
Pre-equilibrating TranswellTM -96 permeable support system.
Fill each of the 96 wells of the U-shaped bottom plate with 200 μL supplemented RPMI-1640 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1699-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Coculture with transwell insert
HGSC target cells (100,000 cells/well) are seeded into a 96-well U-bottom plate. A transwell membrane insert, pre-equilibrated in NK cell growth media, is placed into the plate. NK effector cells (100,000 cells/well) are seeded into the upper chamber. After coculture, the transwell membrane insert is transferred into an empty 96-well plate. NK cells are released from the membrane, by gently pipetting up and down. Samples are pooled from 10 wells into a FACS tube for further processing.
Immerse the TranswellTM -96 permeable support (upper plate) into the wells of the bottom plate.
Equilibrate in a humidified cell culture incubator, 37°C for least 1 h before use.
Coculturing OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells across a membrane barrier.
Aliquot 125 μL OVCAR4 (1 × 10ˆ5 cells) into wells of a U-shaped bottom plate.
Place equilibrated transwell membrane insert (from step 1.c.) into this plate.
Aliquot 125 μL NK-92 (1 × 10ˆ5 cells) into transwells.
Incubate the dual chamber 96-well plate (OVCAR4, bottom chamber and NK-92 cells, upper chamber) at 37°C for 6 h (see further details below for time course).
Collecting NK-92 cells cocultured across a membrane barrier.
Lift transwell insert and place in an empty sterile 96-well plate.

Release NK-92 cells from membrane by gently pipetting up and down.
Pool cells from 10 transwells into 5 mL FACS tubes as described above (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 15.b.–e., Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Samples can be processed for CyTOF or fluorescence-based flow cytometry (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin], “processing samples for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.7],” and “titrating antibodies for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.8]”, steps 16–27).
Determining the kinetics of CD9 uptake by NK-92 cells
Timing: 3.5–10 h
Trogocytosis occurs within minutes of cell-cell contact and involves the transfer of plasma membrane fragments from one cell to another (Miyake and Karasuyama, 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib19]; Reed et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib22]). In a kinetic assay we detected CD9+ NK-92 cells within 15 min of starting the coculture, with a steady increase up to 360 min (Gonzalez et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Coculturing NK-92 cells and OVCAR4 cells over time.
NK-92 and OVCAR4 cells (1:1 ratio) were cocultured for 15, 30, 60, 120 and 360 min in a humidified cell culture incubator, 37°C.
To measure frequencies of CD9+ NK-92 cells after coculture follow the steps described above (“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 13 and 14).
For CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry follow Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, “processing samples for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.7]”, “titrating antibodies for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.8]” and “Determining data quality and gating viable cell population before analysis”, steps 16–29.
Analyze FCS files and plot data (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Inhibiting trogocytosis
Timing: 7–9 h

Further evidence that trogocytosis is the mechanism of protein transfer from one cell to another, requires cocultures to be performed in the presence of cytoskeletal inhibitors (Aucher et al., 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Gary et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Gonzalez et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; Reed and Wetzel, 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib23]; Vanherberghen et al., 2004[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib29]). Available inhibitors include concanamycin A, latrunculin, cytochalasin A, cytochalasin D, EDTA, LY294002 and nocodazole, each capable of altering the cytoskeleton. In our study, of those tested, cytochalasin D was the most inhibitory (range 34%–53%) (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
Pre-treating NK-92 cells with inhibitors of trogocytosis.
Pre-incubate NK-92 cells (1 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL) with: concanamycin A (100 nM), cytochalasin D (10 μM), EDTA (2 mM), LY294002 (10 μM) or nocodazole (100 nM), with appropriate vehicle controls, 2 h, 37°C (See “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]: Trogocytosis inhibitors”).
During incubation period, prepare 500 μL of 0.5 × 10ˆ6 target cells (HGSC or non-HGSC cell lines) in FACS tubes.
Add 500 μL NK-92 cells pre-treated with inhibitor (a) to FACS tubes containing target cells (effector : target ratio of 1 : 1 at 0.5 × 10ˆ6 cells for each line).
Centrifuge cocultures to maximize cell-cell contact, 200g, 2 min, 20°C–26°C.
Incubate cocultures, 3 h, 37°C. There are no media changes, and the inhibitor added (step 5.a.) is present for duration of coculture.
Note: Given that trogocytosis inhibitors block proteins within the cytoskeleton, we adjusted co-culture incubation times to maximize CD9 uptake while minimizing overall cellular toxicity.
Note: Our and other studies have indicated that the block on trogocytosis may vary from inhibitor to inhibitor. It is therefore advisable to perform pilot experiments to find the most potent inhibitor for the cells being studied.

Processing inhibitor-treated cocultures for CyTOF or fluorescence cytometry (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin],” “processing samples for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.7]” and “titrating antibodies for CyTOF and fluorescence-based flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.8]”, steps 16–27).
Analyze FCS files and plot data (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
For CyTOF analysis, gate the following populations sequentially after bead normalization: (i) nucleated cells (DNA1 (191-Ir) vs DNA2 (193-Ir), (ii) singlets (DNA vs event length), (iii) live cells (cisplatin-negative), (iv) viable cells (c-PARP-negative), (v) NK-92 cells (CD45+).
For fluorescence-based flow cytometry analysis, gate the following populations sequentially: (i) singlets (FSC-A vs FSC-H), (ii) cells (FSC-A vs SSC-A), (iii) live cells (DAPI-negative or Aqua-negative), (iv) NK-92 cells (CD45+).
Investigating potential intracellular pools of CD9
Timing: 4 h
To verify that the presence of CD9 on NK-92 cells is due to its transfer from OVCAR4 cells, and not due to trafficking from their own pre-existing intracellular pools induced by intercellular synapse formation (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Determining intracellular pools of CD9.
Process NK-92 and OVCAR4 cells grown in monoculture for live/dead cell staining with cisplatin and fix with PFA (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 16, 17, and 18).
Wash cells with 4 mL CSM, centrifuge 500g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend in 90 μL CSM, add 5 μL Fc-Block, incubate, 10 min, 20°C–26°C.
To detect surface CD9, add 5 μL of anti-CD9-phycoerythrin (PE), incubate on shaker 45 min, 20°C–26°C.
Wash once with 4 mL CSM, centrifuge 500g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL CSM.
Add 1 μL anti-PE-165Ho, incubate 30 min, 20°C–26°C.
Optional: Instead of two-step antibody staining, (steps 8.d.–g.) anti-CD9 conjugated directly to another metal can be used.
Wash once with 4 mL CSM, centrifuge 500g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.

Permeabilize cells by resuspending in 1 mL 100% ice-cold methanol and incubate on ice, 10 min.
Wash twice with 4 mL CSM, centrifuge 500g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
To detect intracellular CD9, resuspend cells in 100 μL CSM with 0.5 μL anti-CD9-156Gd antibody and incubate 1 h, 20°C–26°C.
Wash twice with 4 mL CSM, centrifuge 500g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Add 1 mL freshly prepared DNA-iridium intercalator solution.
Incubate for 1 h, 20°C–26°C or up to 48 h, 4°C.
Introduce samples into mass cytometer (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 23).
Analyze FCS files and plot data (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 28) (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Note: This protocol also applies to staining cells for fluorescence-based flow cytometry.
Fluorescence-activated cell sorting of CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 populations after coculture
Timing: 2 days
Ruling out that a trogocytosed protein is not endogenously produced but that it is being transferred from an interacting cell is an important mechanistic validation (Caumartin et al., 2007[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Gonzalez et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; Nakayama et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20]; Hasim et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]). To this end we looked for the presence of CD9 transcripts using the reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). We describe the steps for isolating CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 cells from cocultures by fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS). For these assays the number and ratio of cells in coculture is study dependent. The goal is to optimize the number of cells of interest that can be sorted from the starting coculture population. In our studies with an effector : target ratio 1:1 we harvested 1 × 10ˆ6 NK cells from the coculture supernatant. Of these around 80% were viable cells. For practical reasons the duration of cocultures was 24 h with no adverse effects noted for cell viability.

Coculturing OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells 24 h, 37°C and transferring the cell culture supernatant to FACS tubes (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 13–15).
Staining cells with fluorochrome-conjugated antibodies for FACS.
Resuspend cells in 90 μL of unsupplemented RPMI-1640.
Add 5 μL anti-human CD9-PE (2.5 μg/mL) and 5 μL anti-human CD45-APC (0.45 μg/mL).
Mix well and incubate protected from light, 30 min, on ice.
Add 2 mL unsupplemented RPMI-1640, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Wash cells twice with 2 mL unsupplemented RPMI-1640, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C, discard supernatant and stain cells with nuclear stain DAPI as a dead cell probe.
Dilute DAPI (1 mg/mL) in unsupplemented RPMI-1640 for a final concentration of 0.1 μg/mL (1:10,000 v/v dilution).
Resuspend cells in 1 mL of a 0.1 μg/mL DAPI solution (above).
Incubate protected from light, 10 min, 20°C–26°C.
Quench with 1 mL supplemented RPMI-1640, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Wash twice with 2 mL supplemented RPMI-1640, centrifuge 300g 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL supplemented RPMI-1640.
Remove aggregates with a 35 μm cell strainer.
Sorting gated cell populations (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
Introduce cells from step 10.l. into sorter, e.g., BD FACS Aria or Sony SH800.
Create gates for sorting using the relevant software e.g., BD FACSDivaTM or Sony SH800.
For singlets, gate on FSC-H vs FSC-A.
For live cells (DAPI-negative), gate singlets on DAPI vs FSC-A.
For CD45+ NK-92 cells, gate live cells on CD45-APC vs FSC-A.
For CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 cells, gate CD45+ NK-92 cells on CD9-PE vs CD45-APC.
Sort using the purity mode.
Collect sorted CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 cells in ice-cold FBS.
Centrifuge cell populations, 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL of unsupplemented RPMI-1640 and count.

Note: At this point, sorted NK-92 cells can be used for different purposes. In our case, we used them for quantitative reverse transcription PCR analysis (next section).
Note: The gating strategy shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8] should be performed for all experiments when fluorescence-based flow cytometry is the readout. (See also step 7.b.).
Critical: Include monocultures of both cell lines as controls for FACS sorting: i) OVCAR4 cells and NK- 92 cells each stained with anti-human CD9-PE antibody, (ii) NK-92 cells unstained, iii) NK-92 cells stained with DAPI.
Critical: All centrifugations must be performed at 4°C to minimize cell death. Sorted CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 cells are collected into ice-cold FBS in FACS tubes kept on ice and protected from light.
Performing quantitative reverse transcription PCR analysis (qRT-PCR)
Timing: 6–8 h
This procedure can detect low levels of mRNA transcripts. A negative result for CD9 mRNA in NK-92 cells would further validate CD9 trogocytosis by these cells. RNeasy micro kit (QIAGEN) was used to isolate RNA from cell lysates and the High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit (Applied Biosystems) was used to convert RNA to cDNA. Preparation of cell lysates from monocultures of OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells as controls for the presence and absence of CD9 transcripts. E-cadherin and CD45 act as positive controls for transcripts from OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells respectively.
Lysing cells for RNA isolation.
Centrifuge cells (FACS-purified and control monocultures, 1 × 10ˆ5–1 × 10ˆ6 cells) 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend 2–5 × 10ˆ4 cells in 350 μL RLT buffer (component of RNeasy kit) containing β-mercaptoethanol (10 μL/mL RLT buffer).
Lyse and homogenize cells according to the manufacturer’s protocol (RNeasy kit protocol[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=5a5aebb5-1603-4a71-82f5-3eb56054417e&lang=en]) and freeze the lysate at −80°C.
Pause point: Cell lysates can be stored at −80°C until they are processed for RNA isolation.

Isolating total RNA from cell lysates.
Perform RNA extraction according to the manufacturer’s protocol (RNeasy kit protocol[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=5a5aebb5-1603-4a71-82f5-3eb56054417e&lang=en]).
Quantify RNA using NanoDrop microvolume spectrophotometer.
Dilute RNA samples with RNAase-free water to 5–10 ng/μL.
Synthesizing cDNA with High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit.
Thaw kit components on ice.
Label PCR tubes and place on ice.
Aliquot 12 μL of each RNA sample into PCR tubes on ice.
Prepare RT master mix scaling up for number of samples (4.8 μL RT buffer, 2.2 μL RNase free H2O, 1 μL MultiScribe™ (RTase)).
Add 8 μL master mix to each RNA sample (final reaction volume 20 μL).
RT-PCR samples (triplicates) to include mRNAs from: NK-92 cells in monoculture, FACS-purified CD9+ and CD9- NK-92 cells, OVCAR4 cells (positive CD9 control). Negative controls to include samples without RNA and without RTase respectively. Final reaction volumes to be made up to 20 μL with RNase free H2O.
Keep samples on ice and gently pipette up and down to mix.
Load PCR tubes into a thermal cycler and set conditions according to High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription kit instructions (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_1699_13.csv
Pause point: cDNA can be stored at 4°C or −20°C.
Preparing reaction mixes for duplex qPCR.
Dilute cDNA (20 μL) by adding 60 μL ddH2O.
Note: Plan experiment for transcripts of interest and controls. For our study we prepared 54 PCR reactions (3 genes, 6 conditions in triplicate) (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]).
Label PCR tubes, place on ice and aliquot 12 μL of TaqMan qPCR master mix containing a Victoria (VIC) labeled probe against GAPDH (control housekeeping gene) and a fluorescein amidite (FAM) labeled probe against one gene of interest (18 tubes per gene) (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]).
E-cadherin: CDH1-FAM.
CD45: PTPRC-FAM.
CD9: CD9-FAM.
Add 8 μL cDNA to each PCR tube.

Pipette up and down with P20 pipette to mix well and avoid creating bubbles.
Transfer mix from PCR tubes to 384-well plate and seal it with aluminum sealing film.
Centrifuge 384-well plate, 300g, 2 min, 20°C–26°C.
Load 384-well plate onto a 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR System and run program below (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_1699_14.csv
Analyze data and plot transcript copy numbers (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]A) and fold transcript expression compared to GAPDH control (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B).
Visualizing transferred plasma membrane fragments with embedded CD9 on NK-92 cells
Timing: 2 days
During trogocytosis, the direction of membrane capture (i.e., which of the two cells donates or accepts plasma membrane fragments) can have important functional consequences. This method is designed to address the directionality of trogocytosis with cocultures prepared where either one or both cell lines have been pre-stained with a fluorescent lipophilic membrane dye. Here, as mentioned above, we are focusing on directionality from HGSC to NK cells. Effector : target ratios are titrated to quantify transferred plasma membrane fragments and to rule out that transfer is a random event. OVCAR4 cells are stained with PKH67 (green fluorescent) and NK-92 cells are unstained.
Prepare monocultures of OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” steps 13 and 14 respectively).
Each cell line is prepared at a concentration of 2.5 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL specified media.
Labeling OVCAR4 cells with PKH67 dye.
Harvest OVCAR4 cells (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” step 13).
Resuspend cells in unsupplemented RPMI-1640 and transfer 7 × 10ˆ6 OVCAR4 cells to a 15 mL conical tube, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Add volume of diluent C for cell suspension of 1 × 10ˆ7 cells/mL.

Add an equal volume of PKH67 working solution to the OVCAR4 cell suspension (final concentration of 5 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL) (20 μM PKH67 was determined to be the optimal concentration (“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” step 32)).
Mix well by gently pipetting up and down and incubate 5 min, 20°C–26°C.
Quench by adding an equal volume of filtered FBS (Steriflip-GP sterile centrifuge tube top filter unit, 0.22 μm pore size) and incubate 1 min, 20°C–26°C.
Centrifuge cells, 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Wash cells with 10 mL of supplemented RPMI-1640 three times, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C.
Resuspend labeled OVCAR4 cells in supplemented RPMI-1640 + IL-2 (2.5 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL).
Keep protected from light before setting up coculture.
Seeding PKH67 stained OVCAR4 cells with unstained NK-92 cells for coculture.
See “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 13.e.–k. and 14.
Seed prepared cells at effector : target ratios indicated (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]) into 96-well U -bottom plate. 10 wells are seeded for each target effector ratio.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1699_15.csv
Centrifuge 96-well plate, 250g, 4 min, 20°C–26°C.
Incubate coculture in a humidified cell culture incubator, 24 h, 37°C.
Note: Our kinetic experiments (step 4 above and data not shown) indicated that CD9 expression on NK recipient cells was maintained for up to 48 h. This provides flexibility when designing experiments. In this experiment we chose a 24 h coculture time not only for convenience but to maximize our chances of measuring a CD9 signal on NK cells especially when cell ratios were not optimal for trogocytosis.
Note: To ensure a detectable signal, the minimum cell number for either of the cell lines was 50,000.

Note: Although the total cell numbers varied between ratios, the data demonstrated that levels of CD9 uptake by NK-92 cells correlated with the number of OVCAR4 cells, which was the goal of this experiment.
Harvesting cocultures.
Pipette cocultured cells up and down before transferring from wells to FACS tubes.
Centrifuge cells, 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Wash cells with PBS, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Live/dead cell staining.
“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, steps 32.a.–h.
Antibody staining.
“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 26.
Preparing cells for fluorescence-based flow cytometry.
“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 33.
Data analysis.
FCS files are gated for live cells (step 7.b.). Data are presented as histograms (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).
Critical: Monocultures of OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells to be included as controls: i) OVCAR4 unstained, ii) OVCAR4 labeled with PKH67 dye, iii) OVCAR4 labeled with anti-human CD9-BV421 antibody, iv) NK-92 cells unstained, v) NK-92 cells stained with anti-human CD45-APC antibody, vi) NK-92 cells heat-killed for LIVE/DEAD™ Fixable Near-IR Dead Cell stain. Cover all tubes with foil to protect from light.
Detecting trogocytosis by fluorescence microscopy
Timing: 2 days
OVCAR4 cells labeled with PKH67 (green fluorescence) are cocultured with NK-92 cells labeled with PKH26 (red fluorescence) as described above. Trogocytosed green membrane fragments with embedded CD9 (blue) can be visualized by microscopy. A total of 3 × 10ˆ6 each of OVCAR4 and NK-92 cells are required providing enough cells for cocultures and monoculture controls.
PKH67 labeling OVCAR4 cells and seeding for coculture.
Harvest monocultures of OVCAR4 (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” steps 13.a.–k.).
Label 2 × 10ˆ6 OVCAR4 cells with PKH67 as above (step 17).
Resuspend OVCAR4 cells in supplemented RPMI-1640 at a concentration of 0.8 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL.

Seed labeled OVCAR4 cells (125 μL/well) in 96-well U-bottom plate for coculture with NK-92 cells (effector : target ratio 1 : 1). Seed a row of 10 wells per condition.
PKH26 labeling NK-92 cells and seeding for coculture.
Harvest NK-92 cell monocultures (Section “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” steps 14.a.–d.).
Resuspend cells in unsupplemented RPMI-1640 and transfer 2 × 10ˆ6 NK-92 cells to a 15 mL conical tube, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Prepare a cell suspension of 1 × 10ˆ7 cells/mL in diluent C.
Label NK-92 cell suspension with an equal volume of 40 μM PKH26 solution for a final concentration of 5 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL in PKH26 solution (20 μM final concentration).
Mix well by pipetting up and down and incubate 5 min, 20°C–26°C.
Quench by adding an equal volume of filtered FBS and incubate 1 min, 20°C–26°C.
Centrifuge cells, 300g, 5 min, 4°C and discard supernatant.
Wash cells three times with 10 mL of supplemented RPMI-1640, centrifuge 300g, 5 min, 4°C.
Resuspend labeled NK-92 cells in supplemented RPMI-1640 with IL-2 (400 IU/mL, 2×) at a volume for 0.8 × 10ˆ6 cells/mL.
Add 125 μL labeled NK-92 cells to 96-well U-bottom plate containing OVCAR4 target cells.
Centrifuge 96-well plate, 250g, 4 min, 20°C–26°C and incubate coculture in a humidified cell culture incubator, 3 h, 37°C.
Live/dead cell staining.
“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 32.a–h.
Antibody staining.
“before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”, step 26.
Preparing cells for fluorescence microscopy and imaging.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL of CSM.
Transfer 15 μL onto a microscope slide and let it dry.
Add one drop of Fluoromount mounting medium to cells on microscope slide, place coverslip on top of slide, press gently and carefully remove excess mounting agent by blotting with a Kimwipe.

Dry for 5 min and image on microscope, e.g., Keyence BZ-X800 (Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12]).
Pause point: For optimal results image as soon as possible. However, mounted cells can be stored protected from light for 1 week at 4°C.
Critical: Controls cells required: monocultures of OVCAR4 and NK-92 both unstained and stained with PKH67 and PKH26 respectively. Protect samples from light covering tubes with foil.
